questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a swelling on her neck for 5 months. It has gradually enlarged in size and is mildly painful. She has also had intermittent episodes of throbbing headache, sweating, and palpitations over the past 3 months. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last for 4–5 days. She does not smoke and occasionally drinks alcohol on weekends. She appears thin and pale. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, 3-cm swelling on the neck that moves with swallowing; there is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
13 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9500/mm3



Platelet count
230,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

136 mEq/L


 K+

3.5 mEq/L


 Cl-

104 mEq/L


TSH
2.3 μU/mL


 Calcitonin


300 ng/dL (Normal < 5 ng/dL)


An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin is a finding of gastrinoma tumors. Gastrinoma manifests with multiple gastrointestinal ulcers and diarrhea and may occur with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). However, this patient most likely has MEN 2, which is not associated with gastrinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism is a finding of Cushing syndrome. Occasionally, medullary thyroid cancers secrete corticotropin, which may lead to ectopic Cushing syndrome. Hypercortisolism may cause hypertension and neck swelling. However, this swelling is caused by fat deposition and thus is neither firm nor painful. Moreover, she lacks other classic features, such as central obesity, menstrual irregularities, or androgen excess symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, virilization).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a finding in carcinoid tumors, which very rarely occurs with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). This patient lacks the key symptoms of carcinoid tumors, which are cutaneous flushing and severe diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism is characterized by increased serum T3 and T4 levels, which can result in tachycardia, anxiety, palpitations, and diaphoresis, as well as thyroid enlargement and neck swelling. In contrast to this patient's normal TSH, primary hyperthyroidism results in a low TSH, whereas secondary hyperthyroidism results in an elevated TSH level. This patient's elevated calcitonin levels are consistent with medullary thyroid cancer, in which TSH, T3, and T4 levels are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

Plasma metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine) are a sensitive indicator of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by intermittent hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, and palpitations, all of which are seen in this patient. This condition is associated with the MEN 2 syndromes and about 50% of patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B develop pheochromocytoma in addition to medullary thyroid cancer. 24-hour urinary metanephrines and catecholamines should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests include abdominal imaging to look for an adrenal mass or genetic testing for MEN 2A or MEN 2B.

Increased metanephrines may also be seen in the case of ganglioneuromas and neuroblastomas, which can be part of MEN 2B syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's neck swelling and elevated calcitonin suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer. This, in combination with a condition that causes the triad of palpitations, sweating, and headaches, is consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man comes to the emergency department because of a pounding headache for the past 3 hours. The pain is 8 out of 10 in intensity, does not radiate, and is not relieved by ibuprofen. He also has associated dizziness, blurring of vision, and palpitations. He has had similar episodes over the last 6 months but none this severe. He has not had fever, weight change, or loss of appetite. He underwent an appendectomy at the age of 18. His father died of renal cancer. He is diaphoretic. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.4°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 220/130 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
14.8 g/dL


Leukocyte count
9600/mm3



Platelet count
345,000/mm3



Serum



 Glucose
99 mg/dL


 Na+

137 mEq/L


 K+

4.2 mEq/L


 Cl-

105 mEq/L


 Creatinine
1.0 mg/dL


Urine dipstick shows no abnormalities. Which of the following findings on imaging is the most likely explanation for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Carcinoid tumors are gastrointestinal masses that secrete serotonin, which causes the classic symptoms of flushing, severe diarrhea, and cramps, none of which are seen in this patient. While in very severe cases, carcinoid may cause tachycardia and fluctuating blood pressure, it would not cause intermittent headaches and severe hypertension, making the diagnosis less likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma manifests with episodic bouts of hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, tachycardia, and palpitations, as seen in this patient. Although the tumor may be found in paravertebral sympathetic chain ganglia about 10% of the time, another location is much more common.

C) INCORRECT:

A meningioma can manifest with headaches and vision changes. But headaches are typically dull, persistent, and worsen in the morning upon waking. Vision changes would also gradually occur rather than be episodic. Lastly, severe hypertension caused by meningioma would be rare.
Image Description:

MRI Head (T1 weighted; with contrast; coronal plane)

There is a well-circumscribed, homogeneously enhancing rounded mass (green overlay) continuous with the falx cerebri and dura of the right parietal bone. It does not invade the surrounding brain tissue or bone.

This is a case of meningioma. This is the most common diagnosis for a dural-based mass with smooth margins and homogeneous contrast enhancement. Other important differentials include lymphoma and metastasis, both of which would more likely (but not always) be less uniform in shape and enhanceheterogeneously.

D) CORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma is most commonly an adrenal medullary mass and manifests with episodic bouts of hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, tachycardia, and palpitations, as seen in this patient. Pheochromocytomas cause an increase in catecholamines and metanephrines, which can be detected with plasma or urine testing.
Image Description:

MRI Abdomen (T2-weighted fat-saturated sequence, coronal plane) in a 54-year-old patient with anxiety, tachycardia, and vertigo.

A circular, well-defined, and hyperintense structure is demonstrated superior to the right kidney. It demonstrates slightly heterogenous signal and does not invade any surrounding structures. The fluid in the urinary bladder (arrow tips) demonstrates hyperintense signal, as this is a T2 weighted sequence. The image is also fat-saturated, as the adipose tissue in the mid-region of the image is hypointense (white dashed lines). There are areas of failed fat saturation in the upper and lower border of the image, where the fat appears hyperdense, as it would in a sequence without fat saturation(white solid line). Depending on technical and patient factors, fat saturation is not always optimal.

This is an example of a pheochromocytoma. They are usually hyperintense on T2-weighted sequences due to their water content.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's family history of renal cancer should raise suspicion for a renal mass. However, kidney cysts or tumors are typically asymptomatic. If symptoms do appear, they include lower back pain, blood in the urine (with anemia and fatigue from blood loss), and reduced kidney function. One rare form, a reninoma (juxtaglomerular cell tumor), can cause hypertension through excess production of renin. However, the hypertension would not be episodic and patients would have low potassium levels.

F) INCORRECT:

Aldosteronoma, an adrenal cortical mass, produces excess aldosterone that causes Conn syndrome, which typically manifests with hypertension. However, due to the high levels of aldosterone, affected patients often also have mild hypernatremia and hypokalemia leading to fatigue and muscle weakness. This patient's normal serum potassium and sodium make aldosteronoma less likely. Moreover, aldosteronoma would not explain this patient's palpitations, tachycardia, and diaphoresis.

G) INCORRECT:

Intracranial hemorrhage is an important differential diagnosis in a patient with severe headache and hypertension. However, an increase in intracranial pressure due to hemorrhage would cause bradycardia (Cushing response), not tachycardia. Additionally, other symptoms such as nausea and vomiting would be expected, and these symptoms would manifest more acutely rather than occurring episodically over 6 months.
questions.hint: The patient's relatively young age suggests a secondary cause of hypertension.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old man comes to the physician after receiving a high blood pressure reading of 160/90 mm Hg at an annual employee health check-up. During the past few months, the patient has had occasional headaches and mild abdominal pain, both of which were relieved with ibuprofen. He has also had several episodes of heart palpitations. He has no history of serious illness. His mother and father both have hypertension. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the past 10 years and drinks one glass of wine daily. He occasionally smokes marijuana. He appears pale. His temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 103/min, and blood pressure is 164/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
15.3 g/dL


Leukocyte count
7900/mm3



Platelet count
223,000/mm3



Serum



 Na+

138 mEq/L


 K+

4.6 mEq/L


 Cl-

103 mEq/L


 Urea nitrogen
14 mg/dL


 Glucose
90 mg/dL


 Creatinine
0.9 mg/dL


Plasma metanephrines

1.2 nmol/L (N < 0.5)


Urine toxicology screening is positive for tetrahydrocannabinol (THC). Renal doppler shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) is similar in structure to norepinephrine, so it is taken up by sympathetic nerve cells throughout the body, including neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma tumor cells. When pheochromocytoma is suspected clinically but imaging (CT scan/MRI) remains inconclusive, MIBG scintigraphy may be performed to localize tumors; however, this patient's CT scan showed an adrenal mass. When MIBG is combined with radioactive iodine, it can be used as a treatment by delivering radiation directly to cancer cells. MIBG therapy may be administered in the case of inoperable pheochromocytoma (e.g., extensive metastatic disease, unresectable primary tumors). This patient most likely has an operable disease with no signs of metastasis. For this reason, MIBG therapy is not indicated in his case.

B) CORRECT:

Phenoxybenzamine inhibits the effect of catecholamines on alpha receptors and thereby lowers blood pressure and prevents a potential hypertensive crisis. This blood pressure management is especially important before surgery because manipulation of the tumor tissue during its removal may cause high amounts of catecholamines to release into the bloodstream. It is important to administer alpha blockers before beta blockers because beta blockers inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors. Therefore, beta blockers alone would lead to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. After sufficient α-adrenergic blockade, a beta blocker may be started for additional control of blood pressure and tachyarrhythmias, followed by laparoscopic tumor resection (adrenalectomy).

C) INCORRECT:

Resection of the adrenal mass is the treatment of choice for operable pheochromocytoma. However, preoperative blood pressure management should be initiated before surgery is performed because manipulation of the tumor tissue during surgery can cause even higher catecholamine release, potentially leading to a life-threatening hypertensive crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

In the case of operable pheochromocytomas, beta blockers may be used for preoperative blood pressure management. However, beta blockers, especially nonselective agents like propranolol, are not appropriate as an initial treatment because they inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors. This effect leads to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. Therefore, propranolol alone is contraindicated in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

In the case of operable pheochromocytomas, beta blockers may be used for preoperative blood pressure management. However, all beta blockers, including selective agents like metoprolol, inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors to some extent. This effect leads to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. For this reason, even selective beta-blockers are contraindicated as the initial step of management in this patient.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of high blood pressure with headaches and palpitations are suggestive of catecholamine release due to pheochromocytoma. An elevated plasma metanephrine level and a mass in the adrenal gland on CT scan serve to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency room for evaluation of a back injury sustained while at work. A CT scan of the lumbar spine shows an incidental 2-cm mass adjacent to the inferior vena cava. Histologic examination of a biopsy specimen of the mass shows clusters of chromaffin cells. This mass is most likely to secrete which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In the peripheral nervous system, catecholamines such as norepinephrine are synthesized in chromaffin cells, mainly in the adrenal medulla. Chromaffin cells are neuroendocrine cells that originate from the neural crest and migrate to the paraganglia and adrenal medulla during embryonic development. Tumors from these cells are called pheochromocytomas, which are mostly found in the adrenal gland but can also be extra-adrenal, as seen in this patient. Besides norepinephrine, most pheochromocytomas also secrete other catecholamines such as epinephrine and dopamine, causing hypertension. Some tumors also secrete EPO, which can lead to polycythemia.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of normal adrenal tissue (H&E stain; low magnification)

Layers from top to bottom:

– Fibrous adrenal capsule (dashed line)
– Glomerular zone (Gz): composed of cells that produce mineralocorticoids
– Fascicular zone (Fz, white overlay): large pale cells produce glucocorticoids
– Reticular zone (Rz, green overlay): eosinophilic cells produce sex hormones
– Medulla (M): composed of adrenaline and noradrenaline-producing cells

No abnormalities are present.

B) INCORRECT:

Cortisol is secreted by cells of the zona fasciculata of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

C) INCORRECT:

In females, most of the estrogen is produced by the granulosa cells of the ovary; in both sexes, it is produced to some extent in the adrenal cortex and adipose tissue. Both the adrenal cortex and the adipose tissue are mainly derived from mesoderm and do not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

D) INCORRECT:

Dehydroepiandrosterone is secreted by the zona reticularis of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.

E) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone is secreted by the zona glomerulosa of the adrenal cortex. The adrenal cortex is derived from lateral plate mesoderm and does not contain chromaffin cells, which are derivatives of the neural crest.
questions.hint: Chromaffin cell tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that usually originate from a tissue that develops from the neural crest.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the physician for follow-up evaluation for hypertension. He reports a 1-month history of episodic throbbing headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal sweating. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. He appears pale but physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated urine and plasma metanephrines. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by the agonistic effect of circulating catecholamines on alpha-1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. Therefore, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for blood pressure control in this patient is a drug that blocks the alpha-1 receptor. Examples of such drugs are nonselective alpha blockers such as phenoxybenzamine and selective alpha-1 antagonists such as prazosin. Beta blockers such as propranolol are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they can worsen hypertension by inhibiting the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors.

B) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is used to treat carcinoid syndrome, which can also present with episodic diaphoresis. However, hypertension in carcinoid syndrome is extremely rare, and other features of carcinoid syndrome such as diarrhea and cutaneous flushing have not been reported by this patient. Moreover, urinalysis in carcinoid syndrome would show increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid, not metanephrines, and carcinoid tumors typically occur in the small intestine and lungs, not the adrenal gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, especially nonselective beta blockers such as propranolol, are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors. This leads to unopposed stimulation of alpha-1 receptors by catecholamines secreted from the pheochromocytoma, which can precipitate a hypertensive crisis. If a beta blocker is indicated, an alpha blocker must be given first.

D) INCORRECT:

An alpha-2 agonist, such as clonidine, has an antihypertensive effect because it decreases central sympathetic outflow and inhibits the release of norepinephrine from postganglionic sympathetic fibers. However, hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by circulating catecholamines, which bind to adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed. A different drug that acts on the adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed would be required to control hypertension in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that is used to treat primary hypertension but not hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of high blood pressure with headaches and palpitations are suggestive of catecholamine release due to pheochromocytoma. An elevated plasma metanephrine level and a mass in the adrenal gland on the CT scan confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit with hypoxic respiratory failure. Her family states that she became acutely short of breath approximately 2 hours earlier. They also report that she has recently been evaluated for labile blood pressure, which at times reaches systolic pressures >200 mm Hg. She has intermittent headaches, sweating, and palpitations but no weight loss.
On examination, the patient has a temperature of 37.5°C, a regular heart rate of 100 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 220/110 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 92% on 6 liters of supplemental oxygen. She is in moderate respiratory distress. No elevation in jugular venous pressure is detected, and heart sounds are unremarkable. Pulmonary auscultation reveals bilateral crackles to the mid-lung fields.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. Serum creatinine levels and urinalysis are normal. An electrocardiogram shows deep T-wave inversions from V1 to V5. A transthoracic echocardiogram reveals severe, diffuse, apical wall-motion abnormalities, with preserved function of the cardiac base.
Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to identify the underlying cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Serum aldosterone and plasma renin activity
Doppler ultrasound of the renal arteries

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone-producing tumors can cause hypertension but not heart failure.

B) CORRECT:

This patient with severe hypertension and acute heart failure has a clinical history consistent with pheochromocytoma. Pheochromocytoma can lead to a catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy, which can manifest as severe, diffuse, apical wall-motion abnormalities, with preserved function of the base. The echocardiographic appearance is similar to that seen in stress-induced cardiomyopathy (also known as apical ballooning syndrome or Takotsubo cardiomyopathy). Electrocardiographic findings in a patient with pheochromocytoma-induced cardiomyopathy can include ST-segment elevation or diffuse T-wave inversion throughout the precordial leads. Markers of catecholamine excess (such as plasma metanephrines or urinary catecholamines and metanephrines) are typically diagnostic in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Key learning point: A patient with new-onset, episodic, severe hypertension associated with an acute cardiomyopathy characterized by apical dyskinesis but preserved function of the base should be evaluated for pheochromocytoma and an associated catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

Renovascular disease can cause severe and labile hypertension, but it is not typically associated with acute heart failure.

D) INCORRECT:

Antiphospholipid syndrome is associated with a hypercoagulable state that could result in coronary thrombosis, but it does not explain the preceding episodic severe hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Nuclear myocardial perfusion imaging can be helpful in evaluating patients for hibernating myocardium, but it would add little useful information in this patient with suspected catecholamine-induced cardiomyopathy.

questions.text:
An 81-year-old man is evaluated for episodes of anxiety and palpitations that last 30 to 60 minutes each and resolve spontaneously. The episodes have occurred sporadically for several months, often in association with stressful events. He has received amlodipine for hypertension, simvastatin for hyperlipidemia, and venlafaxine for anxiety.
On physical examination during an episode, the patient is found to have a regular heart rate of 110 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 136/83 mm Hg, a temperature of 36.2°C, and an oxygen saturation of 97% while breathing ambient air. He appears anxious and mildly diaphoretic, but the remainder of the examination is unremarkable.
The plasma metanephrine level is 0.32 nmol/liter (reference range, <0.5), and the plasma normetanephrine level is 2.0 nmol/liter (<0.9).
What is the most likely etiologic factor underlying this patient’s laboratory findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although anxiety or a panic attack could explain the patient’s symptoms, it cannot explain this magnitude of elevation in the plasma normetanephrine level.

B) INCORRECT:

The patient is at low risk for a pheochromocytoma or paraganglioma because he does not have the characteristic symptoms (headache, sweating, and palpitations), he is considerably older than the average age at diagnosis (47 years), and the increase in his normetanephrine level is too low.

C) INCORRECT:

The patient is at low risk for a pheochromocytoma or paraganglioma because he does not have the characteristic symptoms (headache, sweating, and palpitations), he is considerably older than the average age at diagnosis (47 years), and the increase in his normetanephrine level is too low. In patients with a pheochromocytoma, the metanephrine levels are 5 to 10 times the upper limit of the normal range.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary hypertension is associated with a small increase in plasma metanephrine levels, but the levels remain within the normal range.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with pheochromocytomas classically present with the triad of episodic headache, sweating, and tachycardia. About half have paroxysmal hypertension; most of the rest have what appears to be primary hypertension or normal blood pressure.

Measurement of plasma metanephrine levels is frequently used as a screening test for pheochromocytoma and paraganglioma (extra-adrenal pheochromocytoma), although there is a high rate of false-positive results. Specificity is 85% to 89% for plasma metanephrine levels versus 91% to 98% for 24-hour urine metanephrine levels. Common causes of false-positive results include the use of psychoactive substances (particularly venlafaxine and tricyclic antidepressants) and adrenergic-receptor agonists (e.g., decongestants and amphetamines, which increase both metanephrine and normetanephrine levels). In this case, the increased normetanephrine level is most likely due to venlafaxine use, which causes an asymptomatic but selective increase in normetanephrine. If the suspicion for a pheochromocytoma is sufficiently high, the measurement can be repeated after the patient is switched to an alternative antidepressant.

Key learning point: The medications that most typically result in a false-positive test for plasma metanephrines include tricyclic antidepressants and venlafaxine.

questions.text:
An 84-year-old man reports lower-extremity edema, 6.8-kg weight gain, and left-flank pain during the past 4 to 6 weeks. His medical history includes hypertension that had been well controlled with metoprolol 25 mg twice daily.
His current blood pressure is 180/101 mm Hg while receiving the usual metoprolol dose. Physical examination reveals 2+ lower-extremity pitting edema. CT reveals a 6.5-cm, heterogeneous, calcified, left abdominal mass that is contiguous with the left kidney and is displacing it inferiorly.
Laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
139
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
2.9
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
97
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
25
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
20
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.9
0.8–1.3


Glucose (mg/dL)
410
70–100


24-hour creatinine (g)
1.4
1.0–1.6


24-hour free cortisol (μg)
455
20–70


Plasma renin activity (ng/mL per hour)
0.10
<0.6–4.3


Aldosterone (ng/dL)
<4
4–45 (supine, low-sodium diet)


Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pheochromocytoma causes hypertension but is not associated with the other features of Cushing syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Clear-cell renal carcinoma does not manifest with hypertension, hyperglycemia, and hypokalemia.

C) INCORRECT:

Carney complex — an autosomal, dominant, multiple-neoplasia syndrome featuring cardiac, endocrine, cutaneous, and neural tumors, as well as a variety of pigmented lesions of the skin and mucosa — is usually diagnosed by 20 years of age.

D) CORRECT:

Rapid worsening or new onset of hypertension, hyperglycemia, and weight gain is indicative of hypercortisolism, a hallmark of Cushing syndrome. Symptom onset is often more rapid in patients with adrenocortical carcinoma than in those with other presentations of Cushing syndrome. Symptoms may be caused not only by hypercortisolism but also by local effects of the primary tumor or by metastatic spread. The adrenal lesions in adrenocortical carcinoma are often large in size (> 4 cm) and heterogeneous, with irregular borders and calcifications that can be seen on CT. Very high levels of cortisol in patients with Cushing syndrome can cause hypokalemia through activation of the mineralocorticoid receptor.

Key learning point: Rapid worsening or new onset of hypertension, hypokalemia, and hyperglycemia without long-term symptoms of Cushing syndrome is indicative of a diagnosis of adrenocortical carcinoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Aldosterone-secreting adrenocortical adenoma does not have as rapid a presentation as adrenocortical carcinoma and is not associated with hyperglycemia or lower-extremity edema. In addition, adrenal adenomas are typically < 2 cm in diameter, and aldosterone levels would be elevated while plasma renin activity is suppressed.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old woman is hospitalized after reporting chest pain, diaphoresis, palpitations, and left-sided abdominal and back pain. Her symptoms resolved before arrival at the emergency department. She reports that episodes of this nature have increased in frequency and severity during the past 18 months. Each episode lasts about 20 minutes and resolves spontaneously. Her outpatient clinicians attributed her symptoms to anxiety.
Her blood pressure is 159/82 mm Hg, her heart rate is 92 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.4°C. She appears somewhat anxious. Physical examination is normal.
An electrocardiogram is normal other than occasional premature ventricular contractions. A CT of the abdomen is performed (figures 1 and 2).
Which one of the following medications is most appropriate to initiate next in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Preoperative management should focus on alpha- and beta-blockade. An alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine, should be started first. A beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) is often needed but should be initiated only after adequate alpha-blockade has been achieved. Use of a beta-blocker alone leads to unopposed action of catecholamines on the peripheral alpha-adrenergic receptors, which can worsen vasoconstriction and, thereby, the hypertension.

B) INCORRECT:

Mitotane is an adrenolytic medication used to treat adrenal cancer. Paroxysms of hypertension are not typical of adrenal cancers.

C) CORRECT:

This patient has symptoms typical of intermittent catecholamine release from a pheochromocytoma. The CT scan shows a large left-sided mass. In the setting of this constellation of symptoms, a pheochromocytoma should be considered the main differential diagnosis. The diagnosis needs to be confirmed with appropriate serum or urine blood tests and eventually managed with surgical resection, but at this point, medical management is the main priority. This includes control of hypertension and correction of volume contraction. The hypertension stems from the released catecholamines’ effects on alpha-adrenergic receptors (causing vasoconstriction) and beta-adrenergic receptors (causing increased heart rate and cardiac contractility).

Preoperative management should focus on alpha- and beta-blockade. An alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine, should be started first. A beta-blocker (e.g., metoprolol) is often needed but should be initiated only after adequate alpha-blockade has been achieved.

Key learning point: Hypertension in a patient with a pheochromocytoma should be managed with an alpha-blocker, such as phenoxybenzamine.

D) INCORRECT:

Neither hydralazine nor the mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist eplerenone would address the underlying pathophysiology of the hypertension.

E) INCORRECT:

Neither hydralazine nor the mineralocorticoid-receptor antagonist eplerenone would address the underlying pathophysiology of the hypertension.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old man presents with a palpable mass in his neck. He is otherwise asymptomatic. He notes that his older sister had medullary thyroid cancer at age 25 and underwent thyroidectomy.
On examination, his blood pressure is 138/86 mm Hg, and his heart rate is 82 beats per minute. A palpable, smooth, 2-cm mass in the lower part of his left thyroid moves with swallowing.
Ultrasound of the neck reveals a 2-cm thyroid nodule with no evidence of abnormal lymph nodes. Fine-needle aspiration reveals cytologic features of medullary thyroid carcinoma, and elective thyroidectomy is planned.
Preoperative laboratory testing shows mildly elevated levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen. Genetic testing shows a pathogenic variant in the RET gene.
Which one of the following screening tests is appropriate before this patient safely undergoes thyroidectomy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Medullary thyroid cancers (MTCs) account for approximately 4% of all thyroid cancers in the United States. Most are sporadic, but about 25% occur in people who carry pathogenic variants in the RET gene; all patients with MTC should therefore undergo genetic testing for such variants.

Pathogenic variants in the RET gene can manifest as an autosomal dominant inherited syndrome of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN 2A or 2B) or as familial MTC. The most common clinical subtype of MEN2 is type 2A, with typical onset in the third or fourth decade of life; this syndrome is characterized by the triad of MTC, pheochromocytoma, and primary hyperparathyroidism.

Approximately 40% of patients with MEN 2A or 2B have pheochromocytoma, which may go undiagnosed. Hypertension is the only presenting symptom in half of these patients. Given that surgery can induce a hypertensive crisis in a patient with a pheochromocytoma, clinicians should take care to exclude this diagnosis before proceeding with elective thyroidectomy in patients with MTC who carry pathogenic variants in the RET gene; the presence of a pheochromocytoma would significantly alter preoperative planning. Plasma free-metanephrine testing is the most convenient and sensitive approach to exclude a pheochromocytoma.

Key learning point: Patients with medullary thyroid cancer who carry a pathogenic variant in the RET gene should have preoperative testing with plasma free-metanephrine testing.

B) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas and abnormalities are neither features of MEN2 nor associated with medullary thyroid cancer. Pituitary adenomas are associated with MEN1. Therefore, a prolactin level is not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Pituitary adenomas and abnormalities are neither features of MEN2 nor associated with medullary thyroid cancer. Pituitary adenomas are associated with MEN1. Therefore, a pituitary MRI is not indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

MEN1 is associated with pancreatic neuroendocrine neoplasia, but MEN2 is not. Measuring gastrin levels is not indicated in patients with medullary thyroid cancer.

E) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram is not indicated in the perioperative evaluation of a patient with features of possible MEN2.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old woman presents for follow-up of hypertension, which was first diagnosed 5 years ago and was well controlled with hydrochlorothiazide (25 mg daily) until about 6 months ago, when her blood pressure (BP) began to increase. During the past several months, lisinopril and diltiazem have been added to her regimen, but her BP has remained elevated. In addition, she has been having intermittent episodes of anxiety and palpitations, which last approximately 20 minutes. She reports no flushing, sweating, chest pain, or illicit drug use. Her physical examination in the office is unremarkable.
Ambulatory 24-hour BP monitoring reveals wide BP variation, with an average of 142/89 mm Hg and a peak of 190/110 mm Hg.
Initial laboratory testing yields the following results:



Patient value
Reference range


Sodium (mEq/liter)
141
136–145


Potassium (mEq/liter)
4.2
3.5–5.0


Chloride (mEq/liter)
99
98–106


Bicarbonate (mEq/liter)
28
21–30


Blood urea nitrogen (mg/dL)
12
10–20


Creatinine (mg/dL)
0.8
0.6–1.1


Fasting glucose (mg/dL)
141
70–100


Calcium (mg/dL)
9.6
9.0–10.5


Phosphorus (mg/dL)
3.3
3.0–4.5


Magnesium (mg/dL)
2.2

Which one of the following tests is best for identifying the most likely cause of this patient’s labile hypertension?

choices.text: Measurement of blood levels of insulin-like growth factor 1
Measurement of plasma renin activity and serum aldosterone activity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Blood levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 should be obtained if acromegaly is suspected. Although this condition is associated with the development of hypertension and hyperglycemia, it would not explain this patient’s episodic symptoms.

B) CORRECT:

When a patient with previously well-controlled hypertension presents with labile and difficult-to-control high blood pressure (BP), investigation of a secondary cause is warranted. In this particular case, the patient has several of the classic symptoms of pheochromocytoma, which include episodic headache, anxiety, and palpitations. She also has hyperglycemia, which is commonly seen in patients with pheochromocytoma.

Markers of catecholamine excess (such as plasma metanephrines or urinary catecholamines and metanephrines) are typically diagnostic in patients with pheochromocytoma. In cases where there is a high index of clinical suspicion (such as this one), plasma metanephrine testing may be preferable to urine metanephrine testing.

Key learning point: Evaluation for suspected pheochromocytoma involves measurement of plasma or urine metanephrine levels.

C) INCORRECT:

A 24-hour urinary free cortisol test is an appropriate way to evaluate for Cushing syndrome, which can cause resistant hypertension and hyperglycemia, but this patient’s physical examination reveals no clinical signs of hypercortisolism (such as moon facies, cervical fat accumulation, truncal obesity, bruising, and striae).

D) INCORRECT:

Plasma renin activity and aldosterone levels should be measured if primary hyperaldosteronism is suspected. However, that diagnosis would not explain this patient’s episodic symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery Doppler ultrasound is used to evaluate for renovascular hypertension, but that diagnosis would not explain this patient’s episodic symptoms of anxiety and palpitations. Furthermore, it is not a likely diagnosis in a patient with normal renal function and no renal bruits or other evidence of atherosclerosis on examination.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department (ED) by her father, who reports that she has been complaining of intermittent heart palpitations and a constant feeling of nervousness for the past few weeks and woke up this morning complaining of headache. On review of systems, she also reports abdominal pain and frequent diarrhea. At her annual physical examination one year ago, she was healthy and had normal vital signs.
Her blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 113 beats per minute. Her physical examination is notable for slight diaphoresis and tachycardia but is otherwise unremarkable. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.2 μU/mL (reference range, 0.5–4.0).
What diagnostic test is most likely to reveal the cause of the patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Positron emission tomography of the chest
CT of the abdomen and pelvis

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

If the metanephrine or catecholamine levels are significantly elevated, cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) should be performed to locate the tumor. The abdomen and pelvis are generally imaged first, followed by the neck and chest if the initial images are unrevealing. Abdominal ultrasound can precede cross-sectional imaging if institutional expertise allows, but fractionated plasma or urine metanephrine levels should still be obtained first.

B) CORRECT:

This patient has severe hypertension, which is new in onset and accompanied by symptoms of headache, palpitations, diaphoresis, and diarrhea. Taken together, this constellation of signs and symptoms is concerning for catecholamine excess from a pheochromocytoma or a paraganglioma. A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor located in the adrenal gland, and a paraganglioma is a neuroendocrine tumor that secretes catecholamines outside the adrenal gland (head and neck, thorax, or abdomen). Both tumors are rare and have malignant potential.

Hypertension is the primary sign of pheochromocytoma in most children and adults. The combination of headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis is considered a classic triad in adults but is less commonly reported in children. Other associated symptoms may include orthostatic hypotension and syncope, visual changes, anxiety, tremor, abdominal pain, weight loss, low-grade fever, and behavioral problems.

The diagnostic test of choice for pheochromocytoma is measurement of fractionated metanephrines, which are metabolites of catecholamines. These can be measured in plasma or in a 24-hour urine collection; for convenience, plasma is usually preferred, although there may be a higher rate of false-positive results. In the setting of a symptomatic pheochromocytoma, the plasma or urine fractionated metanephrine values are typically more than four times the upper limit of normal. Measurement of plasma or urine metanephrine levels has a higher sensitivity and specificity than measurement of urine catecholamines and urine vanillylmandelic acid, which were typically evaluated in the past. Urine catecholamine levels can be measured if plasma or urine metanephrine levels are equivocal or borderline high.

If the metanephrine or catecholamine levels are significantly elevated, cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) should be performed to locate the tumor. The abdomen and pelvis are generally imaged first, followed by the neck and chest if the initial images are unrevealing. Abdominal ultrasound can precede cross-sectional imaging if institutional expertise allows, but fractionated plasma or urine metanephrine levels should still be obtained first.

Surgical resection is the definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma, but medical management is typically initiated for 1 to 2 weeks before surgery. Alpha-adrenergic blockade is usually the therapy of choice.

Key learning point: The diagnostic test of choice for pheochromocytoma is measurement of fractionated plasma or urine metanephrines.

C) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum cortisol levels is useful in diagnosing Cushing syndrome. Patients with Cushing syndrome often develop rapid weight gain, a flushed and round face, hypertension, and striae as well as other manifestations. This patient’s presentation, however, is more consistent with a pheochromocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Nuclear imaging tests (e.g., metaiodobenzylguanidine, positron emission tomography) may be useful but are not first-line diagnostic tests for pheochromocytoma.

E) INCORRECT:

If the metanephrine or catecholamine levels are significantly elevated, cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) should be performed to locate the tumor. The abdomen and pelvis are generally imaged first, followed by the neck and chest if the initial images are unrevealing. Abdominal ultrasound can precede cross-sectional imaging if institutional expertise allows, but fractionated plasma or urine metanephrine levels should still be obtained first.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office after receiving a high blood pressure reading of 160/90 mm Hg at an annual employee health check-up. During the past few months, the patient has had occasional headaches and mild abdominal pain, both of which were relieved with ibuprofen. He has also had several episodes of heart palpitations. His blood pressure is 164/102 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. The patient's plasma metanephrine level is 1.2 nmol/L (N = < 0.5). Renal doppler shows no abnormalities. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metaiodobenzylguanidine (MIBG) is similar in structure to norepinephrine, so it is taken up by sympathetic nerve cells throughout the body, including neuroblastoma or pheochromocytoma tumor cells. When pheochromocytoma is suspected clinically but imaging (CT scan/MRI) remains inconclusive, MIBG scintigraphy may be performed to localize tumors; however, this patient's CT scan showed an adrenal mass. When MIBG is combined with radioactive iodine, it can be used as a treatment by delivering radiation directly to cancer cells. MIBG therapy may be administered in the case of inoperable pheochromocytoma (e.g., extensive metastatic disease, unresectable primary tumors). This patient most likely has an operable disease with no signs of metastasis. For this reason, MIBG therapy is not indicated in his case.

B) CORRECT:

Phenoxybenzamine inhibits the effect of catecholamines on alpha receptors and thereby lowers blood pressure and prevents a potential hypertensive crisis. This blood pressure management is especially important before surgery because manipulation of the tumor tissue during its removal may cause high amounts of catecholamines to release into the bloodstream. It is important to administer alpha blockers before beta blockers because beta blockers inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors. Therefore, beta blockers alone would lead to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. After sufficient α-adrenergic blockade, a beta blocker may be started for additional control of blood pressure and tachyarrhythmias, followed by laparoscopic tumor resection (adrenalectomy).

C) INCORRECT:

Resection of the adrenal mass is the treatment of choice for operable pheochromocytoma. However, preoperative blood pressure management should be initiated before surgery is performed because manipulation of the tumor tissue during surgery can cause even higher catecholamine release, potentially leading to a life-threatening hypertensive crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

In the case of operable pheochromocytomas, beta blockers may be used for preoperative blood pressure management. However, beta blockers, especially nonselective agents like propranolol, are not appropriate as an initial treatment because they inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors. This effect leads to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. Therefore, propranolol alone is contraindicated in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

In the case of operable pheochromocytomas, beta blockers may be used for preoperative blood pressure management. However, all beta blockers, including selective agents like metoprolol, inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral β2-adrenoceptors to some extent. This effect leads to unopposed α-adrenoceptor stimulation, which causes further vasoconstriction and potentially a hypertensive crisis as a result of ectopic catecholamine release. For this reason, even selective beta-blockers are contraindicated as the initial step of management in this patient.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of high blood pressure with headaches and palpitations are suggestive of catecholamine release due to pheochromocytoma. An elevated plasma metanephrine level and a mass in the adrenal gland on CT scan serve to confirm the suspected diagnosis.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes to the office for follow-up evaluation for hypertension. He reports a 1-month history of episodic throbbing headaches, palpitations, and paroxysmal sweating. Blood pressure is 160/90 mm Hg. He appears pale but physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated urine and plasma metanephrines. A CT scan of the abdomen shows a mass in the left adrenal gland. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by the agonistic effect of circulating catecholamines on alpha-1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. Therefore, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for blood pressure control in this patient is a drug that blocks the alpha-1 receptor. Examples of such drugs are nonselective alpha blockers such as phenoxybenzamine and selective alpha-1 antagonists such as prazosin. Beta blockers such as propranolol are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they can worsen hypertension by inhibiting the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors.

B) INCORRECT:

Octreotide is used to treat carcinoid syndrome, which can also present with episodic diaphoresis. However, hypertension in carcinoid syndrome is extremely rare, and other features of carcinoid syndrome such as diarrhea and cutaneous flushing have not been reported by this patient. Moreover, urinalysis in carcinoid syndrome would show increased 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid, not metanephrines, and carcinoid tumors typically occur in the small intestine and lungs, not the adrenal gland.

C) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, especially nonselective beta blockers such as propranolol, are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors. This leads to unopposed stimulation of alpha-1 receptors by catecholamines secreted from the pheochromocytoma, which can precipitate a hypertensive crisis. If a beta blocker is indicated, an alpha blocker must be given first.

D) INCORRECT:

An alpha-2 agonist, such as clonidine, has an antihypertensive effect because it decreases central sympathetic outflow and inhibits the release of norepinephrine from postganglionic sympathetic fibers. However, hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by circulating catecholamines, which bind to adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed. A different drug that acts on the adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed would be required to control hypertension in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that is used to treat primary hypertension but not hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of high blood pressure with headaches and palpitations are suggestive of catecholamine release due to pheochromocytoma. An elevated plasma metanephrine level and a mass in the adrenal gland on the CT scan confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to the office because of a swelling on her neck for 5 months. It has gradually enlarged in size and is mildly painful. She has also had intermittent episodes of throbbing headache, sweating, and palpitations over the past 3 months. She appears thin and pale. Her temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. Examination shows a firm, 3-cm swelling on the neck that moves with swallowing; there is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. Serum studies show:


Na+

136 mEq/L


K+

3.5 mEq/L


Cl-

104 mEq/L


TSH
2.3 μU/mL


Calcitonin

300 ng/dL (Normal < 5 ng/dL)


An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin is a finding of gastrinoma tumors. Gastrinoma manifests with multiple gastrointestinal ulcers and diarrhea and may occur with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). However, this patient most likely has MEN 2, which is not associated with gastrinoma.

B) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism is a finding of Cushing syndrome. Occasionally, medullary thyroid cancers secrete corticotropin, which may lead to ectopic Cushing syndrome. Hypercortisolism may cause hypertension and neck swelling. However, this swelling is caused by fat deposition and thus is neither firm nor painful. Moreover, she lacks other classic features, such as central obesity, menstrual irregularities, or androgen excess symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, virilization).

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a finding in carcinoid tumors, which very rarely occurs with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). This patient lacks the key symptoms of carcinoid tumors, which are cutaneous flushing and severe diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism is characterized by increased serum T3 and T4 levels, which can result in tachycardia, anxiety, palpitations, and diaphoresis, as well as thyroid enlargement and neck swelling. In contrast to this patient's normal TSH, primary hyperthyroidism results in a low TSH, whereas secondary hyperthyroidism results in an elevated TSH level. This patient's elevated calcitonin levels are consistent with medullary thyroid cancer, in which TSH, T3, and T4 levels are usually normal.

E) CORRECT:

Plasma metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine) are a sensitive indicator of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by intermittent hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, and palpitations, all of which are seen in this patient. This condition is associated with the MEN 2 syndromes and about 50% of patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B develop pheochromocytoma in addition to medullary thyroid cancer. 24-hour urinary metanephrines and catecholamines should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests include abdominal imaging to look for an adrenal mass or genetic testing for MEN 2A or MEN 2B.

Increased metanephrines may also be seen in the case of ganglioneuromas and neuroblastomas, which can be part of MEN 2B syndrome.
questions.hint: This patient's neck swelling and elevated calcitonin suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer. This, in combination with a condition that causes the triad of palpitations, sweating, and headaches, is consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman presents with two months of episodic headaches, intense sweating, and palpitations. Imaging shows a 4-cm right suprarenal mass. Laboratory results show markedly elevated plasma fractionated metanephrines. She is scheduled for operative removal of the mass. On examination today, she has labile blood pressure and occasional tachyarrhythmias. Her hemoglobin, electrolytes, and renal function are normal.


Heart rate
98/min


Blood pressure
Ranges from 155/90 mm Hg to 190/110 mm Hg



Which of the following medications is most appropriate to start first for her blood pressure control prior to surgery?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In pheochromocytoma, using a beta-blocker before alpha blockade can lead to unopposed alpha-adrenergic activity, increasing vasoconstriction and potentially causing a hypertensive crisis. Alpha blockade should be established first to mitigate catecholamine effects before addressing tachyarrhythmias with beta-blockers.

B) INCORRECT:

Short-acting dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers cause vasodilation but do not address the alpha-adrenergic stimulation causing severe vasoconstriction in pheochromocytoma. Their short duration and potential to trigger reflex tachycardia make them suboptimal for managing catecholamine-induced hypertension.

C) CORRECT:

In pheochromocytoma, catecholamine excess leads to hypertension and tachyarrhythmias. An irreversible alpha-adrenergic receptor antagonist, such as phenoxybenzamine, provides sustained vasodilation by inhibiting catecholamine-mediated vasoconstriction. This blockade is crucial for stabilizing blood pressure and preventing hypertensive crises during tumor manipulation. Alpha blockade must be established before beta-blockade to avoid unopposed alpha stimulation, which can exacerbate hypertension. This approach optimizes hemodynamic stability before adrenalectomy.

Key learning point: In pheochromocytoma, characterized by excessive catecholamine secretion, the first-line treatment for hypertension is the use of alpha blockers to prevent catecholamine-induced vasoconstriction.

D) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin II receptor antagonists target the renin-angiotensin system, not catecholamine-mediated effects. In pheochromocytoma, hypertension results from catecholamine surges acting on alpha-adrenergic receptors. These antagonists do not address the acute blood pressure changes driven by catecholamine excess.

An alpha-2 agonist, such as clonidine, has an antihypertensive effect because it decreases central sympathetic outflow and inhibits the release of norepinephrine from postganglionic sympathetic fibers. However, hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by circulating catecholamines, which bind to adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed. A different drug that acts on the adrenergic receptors in the vascular bed would be required to control hypertension in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide is a diuretic that is used to treat primary hypertension but not hypertension caused by pheochromocytoma.

D) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers, especially nonselective beta blockers such as propranolol, are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they inhibit the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors. This leads to unopposed stimulation of alpha-1 receptors by catecholamines secreted from the pheochromocytoma, which can precipitate a hypertensive crisis. If a beta blocker is indicated, an alpha blocker must be given first.

E) CORRECT:

Hypertension in pheochromocytoma is caused by the agonistic effect of circulating catecholamines on alpha-1 receptors of vascular smooth muscle. Therefore, the most appropriate initial pharmacotherapy for blood pressure control in this patient is a drug that blocks the alpha-1 receptor. Examples of such drugs are nonselective alpha blockers such as phenoxybenzamine and selective alpha-1 antagonists such as prazosin. Beta blockers such as propranolol are not appropriate as an initial treatment for pheochromocytoma because they can worsen hypertension by inhibiting the vasodilatory effect of peripheral beta-2 receptors.

Key learning point: Initial management of pheochromocytoma requires alpha-adrenergic blockade (e.g., phenoxybenzamine) before any beta blocker to prevent hypertensive crisis from unopposed alpha stimulation.
questions.hint: Recurrent episodes of high blood pressure with headaches and palpitations are suggestive of catecholamine release due to pheochromocytoma. An elevated plasma metanephrine level and a mass in the adrenal gland on the CT scan confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: You are seeing a 9-year-old girl in the emergency department. Her father reports that she has had intermittent heart palpitations and a constant feeling of nervousness for the past few weeks. This morning, she woke up with a headache. On review of systems, she also reports abdominal pain and frequent diarrhea. Her blood pressure is 150/95 mm Hg, and her heart rate is 113 beats per minute. On examination, she has slight diaphoresis and tachycardia; the rest of the examination is unremarkable. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone level is 2.2 mIU/L (0.34–5.60). Which one of the following diagnostic tests is most likely to reveal the cause of her symptoms?

choices.text: CT of the abdomen and pelvis.
Positron emission tomography of the chest.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient has severe hypertension, which is new in onset and accompanied by symptoms of headache, palpitations, diaphoresis, and diarrhea. Taken together, this constellation of signs and symptoms is concerning for catecholamine excess from a pheochromocytoma or a paraganglioma. A pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor located in the adrenal gland, and a paraganglioma is a neuroendocrine tumor that secretes catecholamines outside the adrenal gland (head and neck, thorax, or abdomen). Both tumors are rare and have malignant potential. Hypertension is the primary sign of pheochromocytoma in most children and adults. The combination of headache, palpitations, and diaphoresis is considered a classic triad in adults but is less commonly reported in children. Other associated symptoms may include orthostatic hypotension and syncope, visual changes, anxiety, tremor, abdominal pain, weight loss, low-grade fever, and behavioral problems. The diagnostic test of choice for pheochromocytoma is measurement of fractionated metanephrines, which are metabolites of catecholamines.

Key learning point: The diagnostic test of choice for pheochromocytoma is measurement of fractionated plasma or urine metanephrines.

B) INCORRECT:

If the metanephrine or catecholamine levels are significantly elevated, cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) should be performed to locate the tumor. The abdomen and pelvis are generally imaged first, followed by the neck and chest if the initial images are unrevealing. Abdominal ultrasound can precede cross-sectional imaging if institutional expertise allows, but fractionated plasma or urine metanephrine levels should still be obtained first.

C) INCORRECT:

If the metanephrine or catecholamine levels are significantly elevated, cross-sectional imaging (CT or MRI) should be performed to locate the tumor. The abdomen and pelvis are generally imaged first, followed by the neck and chest if the initial images are unrevealing. Abdominal ultrasound can precede cross-sectional imaging if institutional expertise allows, but fractionated plasma or urine metanephrine levels should still be obtained first.

D) INCORRECT:

Measurement of serum cortisol levels is useful in diagnosing Cushing syndrome. Patients with Cushing syndrome often develop rapid weight gain, a flushed and round face, hypertension, and striae as well as other manifestations. This patient’s presentation, however, is more consistent with a pheochromocytoma.

E) INCORRECT:

Nuclear imaging tests (e.g., metaiodobenzylguanidine, positron emission tomography) may be useful but are not first-line diagnostic tests for pheochromocytoma.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 5-month history of swelling on her neck that has gradually increased in size and is mildly painful. Over the past 3 months, she has experienced intermittent episodes of throbbing headache, sweating, and palpitations. Her temperature is 38.7°C, pulse is 112/min, and blood pressure is 140/90 mm Hg. On examination, there is a firm, 3-cm swelling on the neck that moves with swallowing; there is no lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Serum studies show:


Sodium (Na), blood
136 mmol/L (136–146)


Potassium (K), blood
3.5 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)


Chloride (Cl), blood
104 mmol/L (98–107)


Thyrotropin (thyroid-stimulating hormone), blood
2.3 mIU/L (0.34–5.60)


Calcitonin, blood

300 ng/L (< 50)


An electrocardiogram shows sinus tachycardia. Which one of the following laboratory abnormalities is most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Plasma metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine) are a sensitive indicator of pheochromocytoma, which is characterized by intermittent hypertension, diaphoresis, headaches, and palpitations, all of which are seen in this patient. This condition is associated with the MEN 2 syndromes and about 50% of patients with MEN 2A or MEN 2B develop pheochromocytoma in addition to medullary thyroid cancer. 24-hour urinary metanephrines and catecholamines should be measured to confirm the diagnosis. Other diagnostic tests include abdominal imaging to look for an adrenal mass or genetic testing for MEN 2A or MEN 2B.

Increased metanephrines may also be seen in the case of ganglioneuromas and neuroblastomas, which can be part of MEN 2B syndrome.

Key learning point: Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 is characterized by medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma (with increased plasma metanephrines), and parathyroid abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased serum gastrin is a finding of gastrinoma tumors. Gastrinoma manifests with multiple gastrointestinal ulcers and diarrhea and may occur with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). However, this patient most likely has MEN 2, which is not associated with gastrinoma.

C) INCORRECT:

Increased urinary 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid is a finding in carcinoid tumors, which very rarely occurs with MEN 1 (triad of hyperparathyroidism, pituitary adenoma, and pancreatic tumors). This patient lacks the key symptoms of carcinoid tumors, which are cutaneous flushing and severe diarrhea.

D) INCORRECT:

Hyperthyroidism is characterized by increased serum T3 and T4 levels, which can result in tachycardia, anxiety, palpitations, and diaphoresis, as well as thyroid enlargement and neck swelling. In contrast to this patient's normal TSH, primary hyperthyroidism results in a low TSH, whereas secondary hyperthyroidism results in an elevated TSH level. This patient's elevated calcitonin levels are consistent with medullary thyroid cancer, in which TSH, T3, and T4 levels are usually normal.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypercortisolism is a finding of Cushing syndrome. Occasionally, medullary thyroid cancers secrete corticotropin, which may lead to ectopic Cushing syndrome. Hypercortisolism may cause hypertension and neck swelling. However, this swelling is caused by fat deposition and thus is neither firm nor painful. Moreover, she lacks other classic features, such as central obesity, menstrual irregularities, or androgen excess symptoms (e.g., hirsutism, virilization).
questions.hint: This patient's neck swelling and elevated calcitonin suggest a diagnosis of medullary thyroid cancer. This, in combination with a condition that causes the triad of palpitations, sweating, and headaches, is consistent with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN 2).

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of severe headache, diaphoresis, and palpitations that began 30 minutes ago. She has a history of similar episodes over the past 2 months, each lasting about 15 minutes. Vital signs are BP, 240/130; P, 125; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F). Physical examination shows pallor, tremor, and mild epigastric tenderness. Laboratory studies show glucose 210 mg/dL. The patient's symptoms began shortly after she received a back massage at a spa. What is the most appropriate initial pharmacological management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metoprolol is contraindicated as initial therapy in pheochromocytoma crisis. Beta-blockers must never be used before alpha-blockade because they can precipitate severe hypertensive crisis by blocking the vasodilatory effects of peripheral beta-2 receptors while leaving alpha-adrenergic vasoconstriction unopposed.

B) INCORRECT:

Metyrosine inhibits catecholamine synthesis and is used in pheochromocytoma management for preoperative preparation. However, in acute hypertensive crisis, immediate alpha-adrenergic blockade is the priority to counteract the existing catecholamine excess rather than preventing future synthesis.

C) INCORRECT:

While calcium channel blockers like amlodipine can be used as adjunctive therapy in pheochromocytoma management, direct alpha-adrenergic blockade is the initial priority in acute catecholamine-mediated hypertensive crisis to specifically counter the underlying pathophysiology.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Phentolamine is the most appropriate initial treatment for suspected pheochromocytoma-related hypertensive crisis. As a nonselective alpha-adrenergic blocker, phentolamine directly counteracts the catecholamine excess causing the crisis by blocking both alpha-1 and alpha-2 receptors. Its rapid onset of action makes it ideal for emergency management. The clinical presentation of paroxysmal hypertensive episodes triggered by physical pressure (massage) strongly suggests pheochromocytoma, requiring immediate alpha-blockade to prevent life-threatening complications.

E) INCORRECT:

While enalaprilat is used in hypertensive emergencies due to other underlying conditions, it is not preferred in catecholamine excess.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman is evaluated for episodic headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis, which have increased in frequency over the past three months. An abdominal CT scan for unrelated pain recently revealed a 4-cm right adrenal mass. In the office, her blood pressure is 185/110 mmHg and her pulse is 115/min. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated plasma free metanephrines. The patient is scheduled for adrenalectomy. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial medication to manage her condition in preparation for surgery?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Labetalol has both alpha- and beta-adrenergic blocking properties, making it seem like a suitable choice. However, its beta-blocking effects are significantly more potent than its alpha-blocking effects (approximately a 7:1 ratio). This imbalance can still lead to the effects of unopposed alpha-stimulation and is therefore not recommended as the initial agent for pre-operative optimization.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with pheochromocytoma, pre-operative management is crucial to prevent a life-threatening hypertensive crisis during surgery. Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective, irreversible alpha-adrenergic antagonist that is the initial agent. It blocks catecholamine-induced vasoconstriction, controlling blood pressure and allowing for volume repletion. The principle of management is alpha-blockade first, typically started 10–14 days before surgery. Only after adequate alpha-blockade is achieved should a beta-blocker be added to control reflex tachycardia.

C) INCORRECT:

Lisinopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor commonly used for hypertension. While this patient is severely hypertensive, her high blood pressure is caused by excessive catecholamine secretion, not activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system. An ACE inhibitor would not be effective in controlling her blood pressure or preventing a hypertensive crisis during surgery.

D) INCORRECT:

Propranolol, a non-selective beta-blocker, would address the patient's tachycardia. However, initiating a beta-blocker before establishing adequate alpha-blockade is contraindicated. Doing so would lead to unopposed alpha-adrenergic receptor stimulation from circulating catecholamines, which can cause paradoxical and severe vasoconstriction, leading to a hypertensive crisis.

E) INCORRECT:

Metyrosine inhibits tyrosine hydroxylase, the enzyme responsible for the first step in catecholamine synthesis. While it is used in the management of pheochromocytoma, it is typically an adjunct therapy added to alpha-blockers in patients with very high catecholamine levels or for whom surgery is contraindicated. It is not the appropriate initial monotherapy.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of episodic headaches, palpitations, and diaphoresis, along with an adrenal mass and elevated plasma metanephrines, is typical for pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man presents with a severe headache and palpitations. He reports several episodes of profuse sweating, anxiety, and a pounding sensation in his chest. During today's episode, his blood pressure is 220/118 mm Hg. His medical history is notable for hypertension, which has been difficult to control with three medications. Laboratory studies show markedly elevated plasma free metanephrines. An adrenal protocol CT scan of the abdomen is performed. Which of the following findings is most likely to be seen on this imaging study?

choices.text: A large, 8-cm right adrenal mass with calcifications and invasion of the liver
Diffuse, bilateral thickening of the adrenal glands
A well-circumscribed, avidly enhancing 4-cm right adrenal mass
A 1-cm left adrenal nodule with a density of 5 Hounsfield units
Severe atherosclerotic stenosis of the proximal left renal artery

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While pheochromocytomas can be large, a mass of this size with evidence of local invasion into adjacent structures like the liver is highly suspicious for adrenocortical carcinoma (ACC). ACC is a rare but aggressive malignancy. Although approximately 10% of pheochromocytomas are malignant, local invasion is a much more common feature of ACC.

B) INCORRECT:

Diffuse, bilateral adrenal thickening is not the typical appearance of a pheochromocytoma, which usually presents as a discrete mass. This imaging finding is more suggestive of adrenal hyperplasia (e.g., in congenital adrenal hyperplasia or ACTH-dependent Cushing syndrome), metastatic disease, infection, or hemorrhage, none of which are consistent with this patient's clinical and biochemical findings.

C) CORRECT:

Pheochromocytomas are catecholamine-secreting tumors arising from the adrenal medulla. On contrast-enhanced CT, they are characteristically highly vascular tumors, which causes them to appear avidly enhancing. Most pheochromocytomas are benign, unilateral, well-circumscribed, and larger than 3 cm at diagnosis. This description perfectly matches the expected imaging findings for this condition. Preoperative alpha-blockade followed by beta-blockade is essential to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crisis.

D) INCORRECT:

An adrenal nodule with a pre-contrast density of < 10 Hounsfield units is characteristic of a benign, lipid-rich adrenal adenoma. These are common incidental findings and are typically nonfunctional. A benign adrenal adenoma does not cause this patient's profound symptoms of catecholamine excess or markedly elevated metanephrines.

E) INCORRECT:

Renal artery stenosis is an important cause of secondary hypertension and can cause difficult-to-control blood pressure. However, this condition does not cause the classic episodes of palpitations, sweating, and anxiety or the markedly elevated plasma free metanephrines, which are specific for a catecholamine-secreting tumor.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation of episodic hypertension with headache, palpitations, and sweating, confirmed by elevated plasma free metanephrines, establishes the diagnosis of a pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of recurrent episodes of headaches, palpitations, and sweating. He was adopted shortly after birth and does not know his biological parents. His pulse is 103/min and blood pressure is 160/105 mm Hg. Physical examination shows multiple soft, yellow papules on the tip of the tongue. There is a 2-cm, firm thyroid nodule. He has long and slender upper extremities, and his elbows and knees can be hyperextended. The most likely cause of this patient's condition is a mutation in which of the following genes?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2, which includes MEN 2A and MEN 2B, results from a gain-of-function mutation of the RET gene. RET encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase that plays a key role in cell growth, differentiation, and survival. Medullary thyroid cancer (which develops in almost all patients) and pheochromocytoma are associated with both MEN 2A and MEN 2B. MEN 2A is associated with primary hyperparathyroidism, and MEN 2B is associated with marfanoid habitus and mucosal neuromas.

Early diagnosis of MEN 2-associated medullary thyroid cancer is essential because this malignancy is highly aggressive. High-risk patients identified by genetic screening should undergo thyroidectomy during the first year of life.

B) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the FBN1 gene result in a deficiency of fibrillin-1, which is the underlying cause of Marfan syndrome. This condition typically manifests with long extremities and joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Marfan syndrome usually also have cardiovascular (e.g., aortic disease) and ophthalmologic symptoms (e.g, lens dislocation), which are not seen in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the TSC2 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of tuberin protein, which is the underlying cause of tuberous sclerosis. This condition typically manifests in childhood with ash-leaf spots, angiofibromas, Shagreen patches, and benign brain tumors (most commonly hamartomas). Most patients have intellectual disabilities and epilepsy. None of these features are seen in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the COL5A1 gene result in faulty synthesis of type V collagen, which is the underlying cause of classical Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. This condition typically manifests with joint hypermobility as seen in this patient but is not associated with pheochromocytoma, thyroid nodules, or mucosal neuromas. Moreover, patients with Ehlers-Danlos syndrome usually also have skin hyperextensibility and abnormal wound healing, which are not seen in this patient.
Image Description:

The skin of the elbow is hyperelastic (cutis hyperelastica) due to impaired collagen synthesis.

This, along with joint hypermobility, is a characteristic feature of Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the MEN1 tumor suppressor gene result in inactivation of menin protein, which is the underlying cause of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1. This condition most commonly manifests with hyperparathyroidism and is associated with endocrine pancreatic tumors (e.g., gastrinoma, insulinoma), pituitary adenomas, and carcinoid tumors, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Mutations in the NF1 tumor suppressor gene result in a deficiency of neurofibromin protein, which is the underlying cause of neurofibromatosis type I. This condition typically manifests with café-au-lait spots, Lisch nodules, and multiple cutaneous neurofibromas and optic gliomas, none of which are seen in this patient.
Image Description:

Neurofibromatoses are autosomal dominant-inherited neurocutaneous syndromes that are caused by mutations in tumor suppressor genes. Neurofibromatosis type 1 has a typical onset in adolescence and manifests with multiple neurofibromas, benign peripheral nerve sheath tumors that originate from neural crest cells. Neurofibromatosis type 2 has a later onset in early adulthood and manifests with multiple cerebral and spinal tumors.
questions.hint: This man's paroxysmal headaches, palpitations, sweating, and hypertension are concerning for a diagnosis of pheochromocytoma. His long upper extremities and joint laxity are features of Marfanoid habitus. Together with the firm thyroid nodule (possibly thyroid cancer) and the soft, yellow papules on the tongue (likely mucosal neuromas), these findings raise suspicion for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2B (MEN 2B).
